reviewText:
This is NOT an FS2013 clone so if you want a farm tycoon, farm management sim DO NOT BUY. If you want auto everything DO NOT BUY.

This game is about BEING a farmer. It's hard graft and can get quite tedious. You do have AI of sorts but it's click-done AI, not a pixel farmer you can follow around.

My review gets a + only if you understand that it's about BEING a farmer. If that's what you like, get it. You'll enjoy it.

Now to flesh this out.

- The graphics are pretty good and on on i7/670gtx, it hums along maxed out at 60 (with vsync). Some of the detail is very well done, albeit with a very Euro flavour.
- The tute is on rails and must be followed but once you learn the locations and the techniques it's better to go freeplay.
- Tractor driving is very manual and takes some getting used to. NOTE: *Look* at the lower left for how to change the gearbox ratios.  (And reversing is REAL reversing, not just pressing a down key).
- Some machines are missing cruise control at time of writing. Missing as in, devs probably assumed it wasn't needed. They were wrong and as far as I know, will change it.

CROPS
- Limited but enough to keep interest. (and in reality, not all farms can grow all crops anyway)
- Seasonal variations (a big feature) in yield work fairly accurately and devs are working on making it better.
- Seed prices. Enough to make BEING a farmer worthwhile.

ANIMALS
- As good as non existent. Worth having for the extra income (3k or so per qtr) but there is no management or husbandry. (and it's incorrect for many to believe all farms have animals anyway - a common complaint. Most real" farms are fairly dedicated enterprises. Such diversity is usually reserved for smaller hobby farms
date:
certainly in Australia anyway)

EQUIPMENT
- A bit short in this department (again devs are on it) but there is certainly enough to crop and harvest every field with ease.
- The equipment shop is badly designed and laid out (imho) but equipment purchases are close to a one-off in RL anyway.

FIELDS
- Some nice looking layering is used for the various states and the PDA provides field status etc. as you work.
- Crop yields etc. are RT as you harvest (F2 PDA)

MAP
- Big. Generous number of paddocks. No real monsters but you'll be working really hard if you own even a quarter of them.
- Shop to shop transactions. Poorly done. You gotta drive to the bank

- A good game for players who like the down and dirty of farming. I reiterate though

Playing Professional Farmer 2014 since Christmas. Some glitches along the way but with adequate developer response I think. The lack of complete controller mapping and a limited fuel, fertilizer and seed acquisition system are the most negative for me.  If I purchase all the fields, I should be able to use every farmhouse, etc. I am Glad I bought Farming Simulator 2013 yesterday when it was on sale for $8.39 as I thought it may be better. I am sure it will be fun but a tour around the map and quick use of some of the equipment gave me a real appreciation of Professional Farmer 2014. FS2013 did have some of the features I wish PF2014 had like thorough controller mapping and more plentiful supply acquisition locations but the lesser equipment/landscape detail, ambiance and immersion quality is immediately apparent.

A hint for new or frustrated farmers who are not bootstrappers for getting started:

Play the career mode to acquaint yourself with the nuances of PF2014.
Move to free play, drive to the bank and borrow 250,000 euros.
Drive north from the bank and buy the two largest fields, 8.06 & 7.06 hectares. (Fields #1 and #2 for me)
Drive home and purchase 19 more cows, 45 more hens and 50 ducks from the Ag store menu.
The new fields are already plowed, cultivated and sown, turn the season until the crops are ready to harvest (check by hovering the harvest selection over the fields). Use the workers menu to harvest the 8.06 and 7.06 fields as soon as they are not too young.
Your seasonal yield from 20 cows, 50 hens and 50 ducks will be 3,600 euros and your bank note will be 1,050 euros making a seasonal profit of 2,550 euros on your animals.
Check your animal population at each turn (F3), purchase more from the Ag store as soon as you lose one. Add a cow when at 19, 5 hens at 49 and 5 ducks at 49 (maximum will be 20 cows, 54 hens and 54 ducks with your seasonal profit more with the extra hens and ducks)
After the first harvest of the 8.06 and 7.06 hectare fields, turn your seasons a full year to early spring.
Plow, cultivate and sow the 8.06 and 7.06 hectare fields via workers. (make sure you rotate crops in subsequent sowings, I go down the list in the workers menu. Some crops are more profitable).
As you worker manage the big fields you can use your equipment to plow, cultivate and sow the two small fields that were part of your farm. Harvest them using the worker menu until you have enough money to buy the Massive Combine, Grain Heder and Corn Heder.
Your animal husbandry and workers will generate wealth to start your crop farming quicker.
Repeat this cycle until you accumulate enough wealth to purchase the equipment and fields that you desire. Make sure you will have adequate worker funds remaining before purchasing additional equipment or fields.

I highly recommend Professional Farmer 2014.

reviewText:
I like this game, but it is a budget game and very limited in scope.

You will find yourself repeating the same process over and over again: plow, cultivate, plant, fertilize, advance 'season', harvest, repeat.  Don't expect much variety other than a small variety in plant types all of which are harested with the same machinery except corn which needs a different header and hay which needa a forlift, baler, and trailer.

There are also some basic features missing from the game.  The button configuration menu is very limited as is controller support.  You sell your grain at a single location with no foreknowledge of what you will get for it.  Hiring workers  is done instantly (you never see them working) with a pop-up on the screen saying the work was done.  At this time there is no official modding.

There are a number of additional features of the game that are stripped down or missing entirely.  It feels like they started the game by making the graphics engine and driving physics and then found out that the budget was actually 25% what it was supposed to be and development time was cut by the same amount.

reviewText: This game is very realistic, farming is just as hard in the game as you would expect it to be in real life. Personally, I got bored of it after spending at least 15 minutes ploughing less than a quarter of a field, it takes a lot of time and effort to successfully prepare a field to have crops planted on it. If you are considering investing into this game then make sure that you are a patient person, I am fairly patient myself, but I couldn't sit down for about an hour just to plough a field knowing that when I finish I would then have to do it all again to plant the actual crops. The thing that annoyed me the most is that when I stopped ploughing and exited my tractor, I couldn't do anything until I completed my current objective which was to plough the field. I really wanted to look at the hens and buy another cow, but I must have still been doing the tutorial.\n\nThis game is a decent buy for those who like simulator games, but if you have never played one before, like myself, then I would not recommend buying it. It is harder than it looks trying to keep the tractor straight and I would rather spend an hour playing something more fun and enjoyable.

reviewText: Clunky clone of Farming Simulator with some interesting additions that could have been much better enacted. I have played over 200 hours on FS2011 and 2013 and was looking forward to perhaps experiencing something fresh and different gameplay ideas. Sadly it was not to be. What I got was a poor imitation of FS2013 that despite looking pretty, laced any significant difference to the more mature game. Sure, the idea of seasons, having to change gears and diminishing yeilds seems like a good idea but that's about it. Whilst I have some gripes about the realism of farming in FS2013, this game is worse. My biggest complaint is having to drive everywhere in order to achieve anything meaningful such as order seed, fertiliser, visit the bank or trade equipment. Really? Not heard of telephone or internet? These types of gameplay functions should be handled by drop down menus. If you are going to force players to travel to do these things, at least give them the same busted up old car/pickup that all dirt poor farmers use!!! In addition, (and this is a criticism that holds for FS2013 as well), if you are going to have an expansion that deals with large area" farming such as USA or Australia then at least provide a disc plough not some tiny 2.5 metre Euro plough that is just NOT used in reality."
